Award.AbstractNarration:
Rock arches are dynamic natural structures that bend, sag, sway and shake in response to a variety of environmental forcings. Visitors to these features are confronted with their fragile nature, however few appreciate the dynamic life of what are often perceived as stoic geological structures. The investigators will monitor the ambient resonance of a number of prominent rock arches, as well as daily and seasonal deformation at select sites. Their goal is to understand how arches respond to changes in their environment (e.g. thermal stresses, rainfall), and ultimately be able to discern subtle changes in internal strength over time. Key to their approach is measuring how arches vibrate. Rock arches are relatively simple mechanical structures with measurable resonant frequencies and mode shapes. This project measures resonant frequencies using broadband seismometers. The researchers then generate 3D models of each arch from the analyzed field measurements and input these into a numerical simulation to predict the resonant mode shapes and frequencies, and calibrate to match field data. This multidisciplinary project combines concepts from the fields of structural dynamics, seismology, rock mechanics, and geomorphology, with the goal of establishing a new method to quantitatively evaluate changes in the dynamics and structural performance of rock arches. The research will lead to new understanding of the life-cycle of natural arches, their response to different external loads, and failure processes leading to their eventual collapse. Our project also provides an excellent opportunity for public engagement and science education. In the long-term, the envisioned outcomes may lead to new methodology for assessment of natural hazards and visitor safety.

Rock arches are spectacular natural landmarks that connect visitors with the dynamics and beauty of earth surface processes. Delicate Arch, for example, is an icon of the western United States and is as recognizable as many national monuments. However, there is currently no methodology in place to evaluate the structural health and integrity of these natural landmarks as they change through time or in the wake of a damaging event such as a strong storm or earthquake. Unlike engineered structures, the internal composition and strength of critical elements in natural rock features cannot be known a priori. The only means available to evaluate structural damage requires understanding the structure's current behavior and response to external loads, and being able to sense relative changes in performance. We propose new methodology to evaluate the dynamic behavior of natural rock arches, estimate fundamental mechanical properties, generate data for short- and long-term relative change monitoring, and ultimately provide a means to distinguish elastic and inelastic behavior and evaluate changing structural health. The project's core technique utilizes ambient vibration monitoring (i.e., measuring the resonant frequencies of an arch under weak background excitation and detecting changes through time that may be either progressive or punctuated in nature). The concept used merges three scientific disciplines: structural dynamics, seismology, and rock mechanics, building on established concepts from the field of structural health monitoring. Changes in behavior will be assessed by measuring the spectral characteristics of ambient vibrations and through time-dependent modal analysis. By sensing how an arch vibrates we can interpret its behavior and response to external loading, and detect reversible or irreversible changes in mechanical parameters. Resonant frequency shifts will be related to deformation and environmental measurements to assess driving forces and sensitivity of the monitored arches to external perturbations. The measurements are non-invasive and non-destructive, and all instruments are selected to be mobile with a small footprint. The goal is to establish a new method to evaluate the long-term structural integrity of natural rock arches, some of which are internationally recognized landmarks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project analyzed and monitored the ambient resonance properties of >20 natural rock arches in southeastern Utah. We hypothesized that the resonance properties of rock arches could be deduced from ambient in-situ seismic recordings, and that resonant frequency peaks would be sufficiently clear to be tracked over time between repeat or continuous measurements, serving as the basis for a non-destructive structural health monitoring method appropriate for geological features with limited physical access and high cultural value. Results of the study have possible outcomes for hazard assessment and conservation management of these iconic desert landforms.

One key result of the study was that the resonance properties of rock arches can be measured from ambient vibration data. Frequency peaks were found to be strong and readily apparent indicating several resonant modes of each arch. Frequency and polarization data were used to constrain 3D numerical models for full modal analysis of each arch. The models revealed details of the mode shapes for each natural frequency, and in turn resulted in a calibrated estimate of elastic modulus (or stiffness) for the arches. Natural arches were found to exhibit relatively simple mode shapes, akin to a man-made bridge, of vertical and horizontal bending, plus torsion. Elastic modulus was found to vary with systematically with iron content of the host rock. The results demonstrated that the technique of ambient resonance modal analysis is viable for structural health monitoring of rock arches as well as similar freestanding geologic features in a wide range of possible environments.

Ambient vibration field data also revealed that resonant frequencies of rock arches vary measurably at most sites throughout the day as well as seasonally. Two trends were apparent in our data where resonant frequencies were observed to increase with increasing temperature, and again as temperatures fell below freezing. The former we attribute to thermal stiffening, where thermal expansion of the rock lintel results in compressive stresses causing grain boundaries and cracks to close, while the latter we attribute to ice growth at grain contacts (even in these relatively dry host rocks). Both mechanisms result in cycles of rock stiffening and relaxation, generating cyclic changes in resonant frequencies. The results showed that rock material properties are themselves dynamic, exhibiting measurable changes over the course of several hours, and have important implications for damage detection from repeat and continuous vibration monitoring data.

These and other results from this project were presented at scientific meetings and submitted to professional academic journals. Our findings were also publicized in various public media outlets, and were the basis for several public presentations. We additionally supported artistic works and outreach by translating ambient vibration data to sound. This project provided partial support for a Ph.D. student, an M.S. student, and two undergraduate researchers.
